Including narration for audio-type learners.  As the concepts and information provided is thorough, evidence-based, illustrated using examples/cases—and therefore, plentiful—greater visual differentiation of the various types of information (e.g. perhaps, statistical data from studies vs. interpretations of its findings/implications vs. examples of its application) being provided/taught could help further organize all the information. This could be achieved using different font sizes/styles/colors, or even different locations on the screen (e.g. supplemental info or statistics could be put off to the side and/or be in a different color).

The technical part of medicine, ( the overwhelming amount of medications and side effects- the documentation- endless tasks that have little to do with patient care- dealing with insurances- lack of patient funds- medication refills, etc.) has highjacked the PCPs and patients time. We are constantly in a rush. It sucks for both the patient and provider. The proper care of a patient requires time and patience to emerge. What we have now in the USA sucks, for patients and providers but not for the pharmaceutical and insurance companies! We need at least 1/2h per patient and that is not even enough in many cases. 15- 20 minutes is negligent.

There were some questions I disagreed with. In case 4, there is a question and the answer was the child would react different when older, which is true. But, the trauma symptoms that the child displayed required a professional response - this answer was deemed incorrect as an answer.  Yet, the doctor in the scenario did precisely that - refer to a mental health professional. That was not a well thought out question, for me.

It was a well thought out training with many different scenarios covering multiple real life situations. I appreciated the sample conversations between the doctors and the patients to recognize the different ways to speak to show empathy, to prompt the individuals to reflect and open up, and ultimately moving them to acknowledge the "stress and trauma" in their lives and coming to terms with them or finding a solution. If every clinic/health community can achieve that level, that is great. I believe it will take more training for the healthcare professionals to effectively practice ACE assessments because it is almost like being a psychologist/counselor themselves when that is not their professional study. Empathy is not a natural character or skill for all, so that takes time and work to develop. I enjoyed that specialty case where they acknowledged the burnout that professional staff face. It is always a great motto to take care of your own staff. What particularly warmed my heart in that training case was how they recognized they failed to prepare their staff first, acknowledged and apologized for that, and worked to fix it, and set up monthly staff meetings to discuss cases together to learn together and to show team spirit and support for one another.

"A problem I regularly see with these sorts of initiatives is that they choose to identify trauma in black and POC communities without clearly identifying what we know very plainly to be causes of this trauma. We do our patients, physicians, and other healthcare workers a disservice by talking in vague terms about things like ""community violence"" without discussing very real sources of poverty and violence that are directly linked to systemic oppression such as racism and police brutality and its role in the criminalization and incarceration of black and POC communities. Initiatives like ACEs can actually be harmful because they point out the ways that trauma of these communities can be harmful without discussing the actual root causes of trauma. They also do not discuss how trauma, understood as an ongoing response to an isolated incident or continued experience of violence, serves to protect people or act as an important mode of resistance. This negligence of systemic violence may be politically expedient to the makers of the program, or perhaps is a result of ignorance of these issues, both of which need to finally be addressed in the health care system. These problems cannot continue to be framed only in terms of how they affect a person's ability to optimally function in a system that actively deprioritizes their health and well-being, oppresses and criminalizes them. We need more frank and open discussions about the systems that lead to the discussed issues, we need resource investment - including substantial time and money - by the health care community in working to combat these systems, rather than spending all of our time and effort studying poor folks and creating approaches that continue to fail to recognize and act against the systemic violence enacted upon them.

"I loved the cases and the course.   The cases were BEAUTIFUL, the modeling of behavior was seriously lovely.  I would very much like my residents to do this course!   But the substitution of repeated statements about how  wonderfully evidence based all the recommendations are -- and ZERO presentation of ANY of the evidence -- ultimately this will weaken the case for ""trauma informed care.""   I have been involved in the generation of evidence that has changed medical practice and produced population level changes in mortality and avoidable premature death.  My suggestion: how about talking to some of us who HAVE changed practice, with evidence, rather than by preaching about how great the evidence is?

2. The quiz on compassion fatigue and vicarious trauma was poorly worded and misleading. Compassion fatigue is a decrease in empathy towards patients. It is not interchangeable with STS, but may be a symptom of it. Similarly, it may be a symptom of burnout, but is not a precursor. I think the distinction between these definitions should have been more clearly spelled out.  After the quiz, it seems like all three of these are essentially the same thing."

I am affiliated with UCLAâ€™s Pediatric Health Services Research Program and UCLAâ€™s Health Care Institute (HCI). For the past two decades, the HCI has trained front line staff and directors of Head Start programs nationally in health promotion and family engagement. Most recently, HCI  has been training Head Start directors and staff across the nation on childhood trauma and ACES who then go on to teach parents at their respective sites. The childhood trauma and ACES trainings have evaluated over hundreds of staff and thousands of families across the nation on increased awareness and knowledge. For example it is common in healthcare and social services for a particular mandated assessment or screening tool but without consideration for what happens next. It would be helpful to medical staff taking this training to show more realistic examples, repeated follow ups and attempts by the provider to address trauma and create change, encouraging physicians to coordinate care with therapists, and continuing to build rapport and connection with the patient over multiple appointments. Trauma informed care is not simply giving the ACES and asking an open ended question.

It's not that we want to spend as little time as we do with our patients, but we have to make a choice. In an extremely resource limited, provider rare area, if I don't care for the patient, nobody does. So, do we limit our care for the individual (not as much individual patient time, address fewer problems)  OR limit the population served  (see fewer patients, contributing to even less access to care)?  This balance was not addressed in the scenarios (except in passing... "it only takes a few minutes" ) and represents the single biggest inflection point for failure of implementation of an ACE's program.

We also generally have a lack of mental health professionals and social services available and additional referrals could overwhelmed an already taxed system. the main problem that all of us will have is adequate availability of mental health services to deal with this. If you simply take children with asthma (10% of the population) with a divorced parent (50% of the population) that means that just on those criteria alone, 5% of children will be referred for such mental health services. That's before you get to patients with multiple risk factors. We don't have enough mental health providers for children in California to deal with this. So there are both practical and ethical questions about screening when we will not have the ability to follow through on the results.
